newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - May 9.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - May 9.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The Constitution Drafting Assembly has approved the draft charter after two days of debate with only one abstention. The passage of the draft charter, which is to be scrutinised by a 33-member panel, came sooner than expected. (BANGKOK POST)

- In addition to his stance that "tea money" offered by parents to schools in return for enrolment of their children should be openly given and received, Education Minister Sukhavich Rangsitphol says he may also have to push for the imposition of an unprecedented "education tax" next year. Before imposing such a tax, however, Sukhavich says he has in mind an immediate solution to the problem of the inadequate amount of the government education allowance - increase the rate of tuition fee reductions for children of government officials. (THE NATION)

- The Bank of Thailand has announced that Thai Danu Bank could take over Finance One Plc before merging the finance company, hoping the decision will speed up the rescue of the finance company. The decision follows rumours of a possible collapse of the merger, attributes mainly to Finance One's huge problem loans. (THE NATION)

- Bank of Thailand Governor Rerngchai Marakanond has spoken out to clear his name and that of the institution he runs. The governor stresses that the central bank is free from political influence and blasts critics who have accused the institution of lacking the courage to take bold measures and bowing to political influence. (BANGKOK POST)
